body: This is related to #1184.

Thanks @rabbah. Will the black box action proxy (not sure what I'm talking about here) remain in Python or  end up in go? 

As it stands it's quite convenient for a python Docker action to just to piggy back on the python image by 'pip install'-ing packages in the base Dockerfile
The action proxy will remain in python (because we can leverage this in a number of action runtimes as you observe). There is no rationale to move it to go.
Excellent news
closing as no longer valid.
@csantanapr since you've worked on flow/installation process, is this still valid?

@csantanapr @sjfink since this is now merged: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/feeds.md#difference-between-feed-and-trigger

is this issue resolved?
With the addition of node 6 and support for promises, I think this is resolved.
No details added - not actionable.
@bjustin-ibm has created some videos that are part of the learn more page on bluemix. Is there a plan to make these available on youtube? (cc @csantanapr).
I'll say yes.   Closing.
They have already been posted to the [official OpenWhisk channel](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbzgShnQk8F43NKsvEYA1SA)
1.   It does not currently support horizontal scaling of controller --- let's keep this in mind since this will come relatively soon.
sorry, I forgot to close the issue when I merged. I'm used to github auto closing for me :-) when using Fixes Closes #xxx

sketch of state diagram:
![img_6577](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4959922/18519451/05af209c-7a72-11e6-9760-01807eb07343.JPG)

edge labels:
- R_i, U_i, D_i: read, update, or delete initiated
- *_f with underbar: operation completes with failure
- *_f with overbar: operation completes with success
- exp: timed expiration

transient states:
- I: invalidate cache entry, and return to S_0
- FF: request fails fast, no change to state of cache entry
@rabbah not sure if a restart is required for ubuntu, I have not tried the ubuntu steps my self recently.

One issue is "sterilize" -- if we don't do something, the docker cache will grow without bound.

One possibility is to introduce a conditional size-based sterilize task to the build-- e.g. if /var/lib/docker exceeds N MB, wipe it.

@dubeejw Could you rebase this PR and resubmit a PG, it has a conflict and there have some changes in go-cli code base.
sorry for the trouble.
Looks like we can use Go 1.7 since CF and BMX plugins are executables, and don't need to be compiled with any particular version of Go.


@ddragosd you're absolutely right about this point: we don't need to build all platforms for local dev.

Hi @ddragosd thanks for giving feedback.

Could you provide more of the logs of the failed build please, so we can determine which step took it so long (possibly hanging even)?

squashed and rebased.

Now covered the packages tests as well.

pg1/441 approved.
rebased with new pg2/148 approved.
How much faster do you think it would be to download the Docker container containing all the dependancies instead of downloading the dependancies through github?

here are the build times from a randomly chosen recent (last 5) travis jobs:

Building 'go-cli' took 4 minutes, 35.051 seconds
Building 'swift3action' took 4 minutes, 11.542 seconds
Building 'dockerskeleton' took 3 minutes, 16.990 seconds
Building 'pythonaction' took 2 minutes, 18.009 seconds

Building 'cli' took 1 minutes, 56.821 seconds
Building 'nodejsaction' took 1 minutes, 21.262 seconds
Building 'nodejs6action' took 1 minutes, 19.464 seconds
Building 'kafka' took 56.497 seconds
Building 'swiftaction' took 49.883 seconds
Building 'nodejsactionbase' took 44.422 seconds
Building 'scala' took 31.803 seconds
Building 'javaaction' took 23.148 seconds
Building 'consul' took 20.933 seconds
Building 'zookeeper' took 14.749 seconds
Building 'example' took 11.564 seconds
Building 'invoker' took 10.828 seconds
Building 'controller' took 9.177 seconds
Building 'badaction' took 1.224 seconds
Building 'badproxy' took 0.605 seconds
I'll investigate. Does this mean we don't want to only build for the local environment?
I think they're complementary improvements.
rebased squashed and merged in 841821e21690e4f812ab3d67ff7578cfbe1801a0
merged 4d9b7c6f40e736bb0c85d712654dc82e90e602fb

We have to see what are the times savings of doing this.

I think regardless the less time we spent building the none-whisk bits and instead pulling down the image it's better.

But to save manual maintenance  maybe we should have single repos for the go-cli image, and for swift3 image. Then configure docker hub to build an image automatically when a new commit get's merge into the image repo.

Another idea I discuss briefly with @dubeejw was to only build one go binary during travis. (linux/amd64). 
Also maybe parametrized this thru ansible environments the binaries to be built, we just need to cover how to handle the tests for nginx downloads
Should we make this the default?

build only one binary by default
and implement a flag that get's passed to gradle distDocker to build all
from gradle you can get the current, os, and arch you can try to get or just assume 64bit
Build all could driven using env variable that way both the build and tests know to do handle build and test all binaries
From the Travis build output: Building 'go-cli' took 1 minutes, 30.747 seconds.

Sure, in my case it got stuck here:
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/go-cli/Dockerfile#L43-L47

I see, still pretty early in the process.

See #1265 for an attempt to soften the issue.
@rabbah PG1-426 was good. The failed test case was not related with this code base. Issue 2533 covers it.
or PG1-445 also approved.
it looks like #1265 is a fix for this so we can move the conversation in there and close this issue if you want.

Having looked through the PR, we should not rename `cli` to `go-cli` and instead move `go-cli` to `cli` instead. The `go-` distinction is no longer necessary once the python cli is removed (and in fact it could be misleading, as in a cli of `go`).

Another point - since we want to use the python version of the CLI as part of the python actions (as an SDK for whisk in python), perhaps an intermediate step is to move the directory into `pythonAction` until we have the plumbing in place to build and package its inclusion. Thoughts @csantanapr?
I agree with RR that we should keep the code around. It really needs to be resurrected as a python SDK instead of completely removed. See #450

@rabbah, I had to leave some of the files in tools/cli in place (wskadmin, wskprop.py, wskutil.py) as other parts of the system that are written in Python rely on them. 

Just to be clear, do you want a "bin/cli" folder, and move "tools/go-cli" to "tools/cli" ?
Also, just to be clear, I've backed up the old CLI here:  https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-python-cli with commits preserved.

is it plausible to move `wskadmin, wskprops and wskutils` to `bin` (we can avoid this way the nasty link issues that sometimes arise in vagrant).
it makes sense to me to rename `tools/go-cli` to `tools/cli`.

I don't like having dead stale code in the repo, but I think if we want to maintain the code base up to date as an sdk lib for python, let's keep it in the repo for now. 

Here is my proposal
`sdk/phython/` (wsk client library for python can be use from inside an action or outside the system)
`tools/cli/` (the go based cli, we don't need the string `go` in directory names anymore)
This one I'm not sure:
Option 1
`bin/wsk` (when the build runs this will be the binary specific to the current OS and Arch)
`bin/cli/[linux/,mac/,windows/]` (cli for all binaries OS/Arch)
Option 2
`bin/wsk` (when the build runs this will be the binary specific to the current OS and Arch)
`bin/[linux/,mac/,windows/]` (cli for all binaries OS/Arch)
Option 3
`bin/wsk/wsk` (when the build runs this will be the binary specific to the current OS and Arch)
`bin/wsk/[linux/,mac/,windows/]` (cli for all binaries OS/Arch)
+1 for option 2; for local development there will be only one anyway that's useful - should these even be in bin vs say a build dir?

@lzbj Thank you for contributing this work. The GitHub trigger code has been moved to the [openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog) repo. I have migrated your changes over to that repo as well as added fixes and additional error handling. Please follow along at openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog#139
Now that the GitHub trigger code has moved, this will be resolved by openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog#139.

Step 2 of the API design:

Each gateway entity will include at least a collection of entities called routes.   A route will specify at least an HTTP Verb, an OW action, and some information about parameter mapping.

The API will support the usual CRUD OW operations on individual routes via:

/openwhisk/namespaces/{ns}/gateways/{gatewayName}/routes/{id}

TBD: Do we let users name routes, or generate unique ids?    I suppose letting users name them (i.e. choose the primary key) is consistent with the rest of the OW API.
Resolved by by openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog#139.
A change to openwhisk-catalog will need to happen to accommodate theses changes.

It seems that a purpose-built Mesos framework might be a good choice, given the somewhat unique requirements and runtime characteristics of OW actions (long-running or not).

Ok this is long overdue, I'll address shortly.
Rebased/merged as 8cceedec5e19b7d61a6291d1c7cc4efa2a0994ce

Four work items identified in discussion with @paulcastro 
- [ ] upgrade Swift 3 container
- [ ] make Swift 3 the default instead of 2.2
- [ ] remove all support for Swift 2.2.    This would mean adding a new error Unsupported runtime: experimental Swift 2.2 is no longer supported.   Please recreate your action using Swift 3.
- [ ] publish an openwhisk/swift3 base image on docker hub and pull that, rather than building the swift 3 implementation from swift.org (should improve build time)
For the record, we understand that NSURLSession is still buggy so we include kitura.net for now.
The limit for the number of actions for a sequence will be a limit specified part of the configuration per deployment (as such, it's present in `WhiskConfig` and ansible all var configuration file).
I think I will close this and incorporate it in the work for #1274 that actually uses it. It's a small code change and better have it together with its usage.

LGTM - can we safely use that button?

@bjustin-ibm and @psuter have advised it is OK to use when you want to squash all the commits into one. "You get the opportunity to edit the commit message once you hit the button. It concats all the commit messages by default (the same way a `rebase -i` would)." Modify as needed.

is there a pg?

@sjfink interesting topic. i think we'd have to define the specific lifetime of a container for getting classified as long-running. today we can run docker containers as part of openwhisk natively -- so we'd have to think through to which degree could we support long-running actions by just raising the max lifetime of an activation vs starting to integrate with a cluster mgr.
Thanks for catching @rr, PG2 176 approved
